electricity_bill.title: Electricity Bill Calculator
electricity_bill.description: Estimate electricity consumption cost based on kWh usage.
electricity_bill.price_per_kwh_tooltip: Cost per unit of energy according to the tariff
electricity_bill.fixed_charge_tooltip: Monthly fixed service or meter fee
electricity_bill.about_desc: Use energy-efficient appliances, turn off lights when not needed, and use thermal insulation to reduce cooling costs.
electricity_bill.empty_state: Enter consumption and tariff data to calculate bill
electricity_bill.footer_note: This calculator provides an estimate; actual bills may vary due to usage tiers and additional fees.

howItWorks.title: How the Electricity Bill Calculator Works
howItWorks.explanation: Calculates your electricity bill by multiplying energy consumption in kilowatt-hours by the unit rate, then adding fixed charges and applicable taxes.

steps.name: Step 1
steps.text: Enter your total energy consumption in kWh

steps.name: Step 2
steps.text: Enter the price per kWh from your tariff

steps.name: Step 3
steps.text: Add any fixed monthly charges

steps.name: Step 4
steps.text: Specify the tax rate percentage

useCases: Comparing costs before and after energy-saving measures
seoTips: Check your meter regularly to track consumption
Compare different tariff plans for savings
Consider time-of-use rates for lower off-peak costs
Factor in seasonal variations for accurate estimates
commonMistakes: Forgetting to include fixed charges and taxes
Using wrong tariff rates (tiered pricing)
Not accounting for demand charges (commercial)
Ignoring power factor penalties for businesses

faqs.question: What is a kWh?
faqs.answer: A kilowatt-hour (kWh) is a unit of energy equal to using 1000 watts for one hour. A 100W bulb running for 10 hours uses 1 kWh.

faqs.question: Why does my actual bill differ from the estimate?
faqs.answer: Actual bills may include tiered pricing (higher rates for higher consumption), demand charges, fuel adjustments, and various fees not included in simple calculations.

faqs.question: How can I reduce my electricity bill?
faqs.answer: Use energy-efficient appliances, LED lighting, smart thermostats, and unplug devices when not in use. Consider solar panels for long-term savings.

battery_life.title: Battery Life Calculator
battery_life.description: Calculate estimated battery runtime based on capacity and load.
battery_life.capacity_tooltip: Total energy storage capacity of the battery

howItWorks.title: How the Battery Life Calculator Works
howItWorks.explanation: Estimates how long a battery will power a device by dividing the battery capacity (in mAh or Ah) by the device's current draw, adjusted for efficiency losses.

steps.name: Step 1
steps.text: Enter the battery capacity (mAh or Ah)

steps.name: Step 2
steps.text: Enter the device's current consumption

steps.name: Step 3
steps.text: Adjust efficiency percentage (accounts for losses)

steps.name: Step 4
steps.text: View estimated runtime in hours, days, or weeks

useCases: Estimating smartphone and laptop battery life
Sizing batteries for IoT and embedded devices
Designing solar systems with battery backup
seoTips: Typical efficiency is 80-90% for DC-DC converters
Peukert effect reduces capacity at high discharge rates
Li-ion batteries: multiply Ah by 3.7V for Wh capacity
Consider 20% capacity degradation for aged batteries
commonMistakes: Ignoring efficiency losses in voltage conversion
Not accounting for the Peukert effect at high currents
Using rated capacity without temperature derating
Forgetting sleep mode vs. active mode current differences

faqs.question: What is the Peukert effect?
faqs.answer: The Peukert effect describes how battery capacity decreases at higher discharge rates. A battery rated at 100Ah at 5A discharge might only deliver 80Ah at 20A discharge.

faqs.question: Why should I use efficiency percentage?
faqs.answer: No power conversion is 100% efficient. Voltage regulators, DC-DC converters, and internal battery resistance all consume power. 85% efficiency is a good estimate for most applications.

faqs.question: How do mAh and Ah relate?
faqs.answer: 1 Ah = 1000 mAh. Small batteries (phone, Arduino) use mAh, while larger batteries (car, solar) use Ah. Multiply Ah by voltage to get Wh (energy capacity).

solar_panel.title: Solar Panel Calculator
solar_panel.description: Calculate the number of solar panels and battery capacity needed for your daily consumption.

tooltips.daily_consumption: Total energy used per day in Watt-hours
tooltips.sun_hours: Average hours of full sunlight per day
tooltips.panel_wattage: Rated power of a single solar panel

results.batteries_desc: Based on 2 days of autonomy and 50% depth of discharge

info.title: System Sizing
info.desc: This estimation includes a factor for system losses and inefficiencies.

howItWorks.title: How the Solar Panel Calculator Works
howItWorks.formula: Panels = Daily Consumption / (Panel Wattage × Sun Hours × Efficiency)
howItWorks.explanation: Calculates the number of solar panels needed based on daily energy consumption, peak sun hours, and system efficiency. Also sizes battery capacity for autonomy.

steps.name: Step 1
steps.text: Enter your daily energy consumption (Wh)

steps.name: Step 2
steps.text: Specify average peak sun hours for your location

steps.name: Step 3
steps.text: Select system voltage (12V, 24V, 48V)

steps.name: Step 4
steps.text: Enter the wattage of your chosen panels

useCases: Planning RV and boat solar systems
seoTips: Peak sun hours vary by location (typically 4-6 hours)
Include 20-30% for system losses and inefficiencies
Higher voltage systems reduce cable losses
Plan for 2-3 days of battery autonomy for off-grid
commonMistakes: Using total daylight hours instead of peak sun hours
Forgetting inverter and charge controller losses
Under-sizing batteries for cloudy day autonomy
Not accounting for seasonal sun hour variations

faqs.question: What are peak sun hours?
faqs.answer: Peak sun hours (PSH) are equivalent hours of 1000W/m² solar irradiance. 5 PSH means the total daily energy equals 5 hours of full sun, not actual sunlight duration.

faqs.question: How do I determine my daily consumption?
faqs.answer: Add up wattage × hours of use for all appliances. Check energy bills for monthly kWh and divide by 30. Use a power meter for accurate measurements.

faqs.question: What system voltage should I choose?
faqs.answer: 12V for small systems under 2kW, 24V for medium systems, 48V for larger systems. Higher voltage reduces current and cable losses but requires more panels in series.

power_calc.title: Electrical Power Calculator
power_calc.description: Calculate active, reactive, and apparent power for single and three-phase systems.
power_calc.single_phase_formula: Single Phase: P = V × I × PF
power_calc.three_phase_formula: Three Phase: P = √3 × V × I × PF

howItWorks.title: How the Electrical Power Calculator Works
howItWorks.formula: P = V × I × PF (single-phase), P = √3 × V × I × PF (three-phase)
howItWorks.explanation: Calculates active, reactive, and apparent power for electrical systems. Active power does useful work, reactive power oscillates in inductive/capacitive loads, and apparent power is the total supplied.

steps.name: Step 1
steps.text: Select phase system (single or three-phase)

steps.name: Step 2
steps.text: Enter voltage and current values

steps.name: Step 3
steps.text: Enter the power factor (0-1)

steps.name: Step 4
steps.text: View all power components and energy consumption

seoTips: Active power (W) does actual work
Reactive power (VAR) sustains magnetic/electric fields
Apparent power (VA) = V × I (what you pay for in some tariffs)
1 kW running 1 hour = 1 kWh of energy
commonMistakes: Confusing power (kW) with energy (kWh)
Forgetting power factor in industrial calculations
Using line voltage instead of phase voltage incorrectly
Not accounting for harmonics in non-linear loads

faqs.question: What is the difference between kW and kVA?
faqs.answer: kW (kilowatts) is active/real power that does work. kVA (kilovolt-amperes) is apparent power including reactive components. kW = kVA × Power Factor.

faqs.question: Why does power factor matter?
faqs.answer: Low power factor means more current is needed for the same useful power, causing larger cables, higher losses, and potential utility penalties for industrial customers.

faqs.question: How do I calculate energy cost?
faqs.answer: Energy (kWh) = Power (kW) × Time (hours). Cost = kWh × rate. For example, 2kW × 5 hours = 10 kWh. At $0.10/kWh, cost = $1.00.

power_factor.title: Power Factor Calculator
power_factor.description: Calculate power factor correction capacitor and other parameters.

howItWorks.title: How the Power Factor Calculator Works
howItWorks.explanation: Calculates current power factor and determines the capacitor size needed to improve it to a target value. Power factor correction reduces energy waste and utility penalties.

steps.name: Step 1
steps.text: Enter active power (kW) and reactive power (kVAR)

steps.name: Step 2
steps.text: Enter target power factor (typically 0.95)

steps.name: Step 3
steps.text: Enter system voltage and frequency

steps.name: Step 4
steps.text: View required capacitor rating and size

seoTips: Most utilities require PF > 0.85 to avoid penalties
Target PF of 0.95-0.98 is optimal (over-correction causes leading PF)
Capacitors provide leading reactive power to cancel lagging
Automatic capacitor banks adjust to varying loads
commonMistakes: Over-correcting to leading power factor (resonance risk)
Not considering harmonic effects on capacitors
Using fixed capacitors for varying loads
Ignoring capacitor voltage and frequency ratings

faqs.question: Why do I need power factor correction?
faqs.answer: Low PF means drawing more current than needed, causing higher cable losses, larger equipment sizing, and utility penalties. Correction saves money and improves efficiency.

faqs.question: What happens if I over-correct power factor?
faqs.answer: Over-correction creates a leading power factor, which can cause voltage rise, resonance with system inductance, and potential equipment damage. Stay below 0.98 PF.

faqs.question: Should I use fixed or automatic capacitor banks?
faqs.answer: Fixed capacitors work for constant loads. Automatic banks with contactors switch capacitor stages based on measured PF, ideal for varying loads like factories.

transformer.title: Transformer Calculator
transformer.description: Calculate turns ratio, voltage ratio, current, and efficiency for transformers.

howItWorks.title: How the Transformer Calculator Works
howItWorks.explanation: Calculates transformer parameters based on the relationship between primary and secondary windings. Voltage ratio equals turns ratio, while current ratio is inverse.

steps.name: Step 1
steps.text: Enter primary and secondary voltages

steps.name: Step 2
steps.text: Or enter primary and secondary turns

steps.name: Step 3
steps.text: Enter power rating and efficiency

steps.name: Step 4
steps.text: View currents, losses, and ratios

seoTips: Turns ratio = voltage ratio for ideal transformers
Current ratio is inverse of voltage ratio
Efficiency = output power / input power × 100%
VA rating must exceed connected load
commonMistakes: Confusing VA rating with watts (consider power factor)
Forgetting transformer losses (core and copper)
Not accounting for voltage drop under load
Using DC with transformers (they only work with AC)

faqs.question: What is the difference between VA and Watts in transformers?
faqs.answer: VA (volt-amperes) is apparent power - what the transformer delivers. Watts is active power after accounting for power factor. For resistive loads, VA = Watts.

faqs.question: Why does efficiency matter?
faqs.answer: Transformer losses become heat. Lower efficiency means more energy wasted, higher operating costs, and potential overheating. Modern transformers achieve 95-99% efficiency.

faqs.question: Can I use a transformer with DC?
faqs.answer: No, transformers only work with AC. DC creates a constant magnetic field that induces no voltage. Use a DC-DC converter or first convert DC to AC.

electrical_load.title: Electrical Load Calculator
electrical_load.description: Calculate total electrical load, current, and recommended panel/cable sizes.
electrical_load.notes: Results include 25% safety factor. Consult an electrician for final installation.
electrical_load.empty_state: Enter loads and voltage to calculate
electrical_load.footer_note: This calculator provides estimates. Professional verification is recommended.

howItWorks.title: How the Electrical Load Calculator Works
howItWorks.formula: Total Current = Total Power / (Voltage × Power Factor)
howItWorks.explanation: Sums all electrical loads to determine total power demand, then calculates the current draw to recommend appropriate panel and cable sizes for safe installation.

steps.name: Step 1
steps.text: Enter system voltage and power factor

steps.name: Step 2
steps.text: Add each electrical load with its power and quantity

steps.name: Step 3
steps.text: View total power and current demand

steps.name: Step 4
steps.text: Get recommended panel and cable sizes

useCases: Sizing main breakers and service entrance
seoTips: Include 25% safety margin for future expansion
Diversity factor reduces total for unlikely simultaneous use
Continuous loads require 125% breaker sizing
NEC requires specific sizing for different load types
commonMistakes: Adding loads without diversity factor (over-sizing)
Forgetting future load growth allowance
Not classifying continuous vs intermittent loads
Ignoring power factor in industrial calculations

faqs.question: What is diversity factor?
faqs.answer: Diversity factor accounts for loads not running simultaneously. A home might have 30kW of loads but only 15kW peak demand. Diversity = Peak / Total, typically 0.4-0.8.

faqs.question: How do I size the main breaker?
faqs.answer: Calculate total demand with diversity factor, add 25% for continuous loads, then select next standard breaker size up. Always follow local electrical codes.

faqs.question: What cable size do I need?
faqs.answer: Cable size depends on current, distance, and installation method. Use ampacity tables from NEC/IEC, derate for temperature and bundling, and check voltage drop.

inrush_current.title: Inrush Current Calculator
inrush_current.description: Calculate inrush current for motors, transformers, and other electrical devices.
inrush_current.load_type_tooltip: Select the type of electrical load
inrush_current.rated_power_tooltip: Nominal power rating of the device
inrush_current.info_notes: Inrush current is the initial surge when equipment starts. It can be 5-15x normal current.
inrush_current.empty_state: Enter device parameters to calculate inrush current
inrush_current.footer_note: Actual inrush may vary. Use appropriate fuses and circuit breakers.

howItWorks.title: How the Inrush Current Calculator Works
howItWorks.formula: Inrush = Steady State × Multiplier (varies by load type)
howItWorks.explanation: Estimates the initial surge current when equipment starts. Different load types have different inrush characteristics based on their electrical behavior during startup.

steps.name: Step 1
steps.text: Select the load type (motor, transformer, capacitor, etc.)

steps.name: Step 2
steps.text: Enter the rated power and voltage

steps.name: Step 3
steps.text: View the inrush current peak value

steps.name: Step 4
steps.text: See inrush duration and multiplier

useCases: Planning generator capacity for starting loads
seoTips: Motors: 6-8x rated current for DOL starting
Transformers: 10-15x rated for magnetizing inrush
Capacitors: very high but brief inrush (limit with resistor)
LEDs with capacitive drivers can have 20-100x inrush
commonMistakes: Using standard fuses that trip on motor starting
Not accounting for capacitor bank inrush
Undersizing contactors for inductive loads
Ignoring inrush when sizing UPS and generators

faqs.question: Why do motors have high inrush current?
faqs.answer: At startup, motor speed is zero so there is no back-EMF to oppose current. The motor acts like a short circuit until it accelerates, drawing 6-8x rated current.

faqs.question: How do I reduce inrush current?
faqs.answer: Use soft starters (reduced voltage), VFDs (variable frequency drives), star-delta starters for motors, or NTC thermistors/resistors for capacitive loads.

faqs.question: What type of circuit breaker handles inrush?
faqs.answer: Use Type C or D breakers for motor/transformer loads. Type B trips at 3-5x, Type C at 5-10x, and Type D at 10-20x rated current.
